content:
There's something off with the last pair of test/validator. This code won't pass the last test but will get 100% score. You may want to fix it.

import sys

n = int(input())
cs = [int(input()) for _ in range(n)]
cs.sort()
start = cs[0]
total = 0
prev = start
i = 0
while cs:
    c = cs.pop(0)
    cur_area = c*c * 6
    total += cur_area - prev
    if i > 0:
        total -= prev
    print(c, cur_area, total, prev, file=sys.stderr)
    prev = c*c
    i += 1
    
print(total)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very cool

Hello,
Unless you specify that the cubes are stacked from smaller to larger, your solution is wrong.
Example:
Input = 2, 1, 3 ==> You gave 73 as the maximum free surface. But if I stack the cubes such that: 2 at the bottom, 1 at the middle and 3 at the top, then the free surface is 4*6-4-1+1*6-1-1+9*6-1 = 76 > 73.

Please update your solution such as all the combinations are tried to find the maximum free surface area. Otherwise, add a statement that the cubes can only be stacked bottom in ascending order.

More complicated than I thought at first glance. It didn't initially occur to me to count the surface area unobstructed by smaller cubes. I was also tripped up by not accounting for the ground. I think it should be clear enough for anyone who reads the prompt thoroughly, though.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good, a pleasure to solve

Ohh, actually I like this.  It's tricker than it seems upon first glance.  
I think it's clear; but a player (me) might not realize for example when a 3-size cube is stacked above a 2-size cube, there is UNDER-surface that needs to be counted too.  
That's great that I had to realize that part-way into the puzzle.  

I really like it, and will come back and solve further later.  Good job!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
UPDATE: I have now solved it, and will give approval.  Great.  A pleasure.

I few very minor things:
~I think "ie." should be "i.e."
~You might (or might not) want to explicitly mention that Bill can stack a larger cube on top of a smaller cube.  It was kinda fun having to make that discovery on my own, but some people might be frustrated with that.  I don't feel strongly one way or the other; just consider it.

âŒ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Ambiguous surface definition ....
What's wrong with the surface area definition? How can I make it less "ambiguous"?
Glad you enjoyed the problem, thanks for the valuable feedback. Will make these changes.

Ok it was entirely my fault but I managed to pinpoint where the error was located. Turns out that this line in my code:

start = cs[0] 

should be 

start = cs[0] * cs[0]

since it's supposed to represent the area of one side of the smallest cube.

Now my previous solution passed every validator (and every test except "Random") since every one of them has 1 in the cube side lengths (always being the smallest ofc, and 1**2 = 1 etc.).

So my suggestion is to just add a short test at the beginning with something like 

3
2
3
4
144 (your correct solution, mine will give 146) 

or some variation of that.

Thanks for your time.
Oh I see, thanks. Will add that now, thanks for the feedback.

Wow, thank you for pointing this out. I must've done some miscalculation whilst coming up with this problem. For the simplicity of Clash of Code, I will rewrite the problem statement to indicate ascending order. Thanks!
I have now updated the problem statement, hopefully it is clearer and easier to understand.

Very good catch yel python.

I didnâ€™t envision that arrangement ðŸ™‚
Nice puzzle, thanks ! I'm glad to be of service.
